TYPES OF BIOMES

Rainforests

They are also called tropical forests. They develop in areas with high temperatures and abundant rainfall during much of the year.

They extend on both sides of the equator in Central America, South America, Africa, Asia, and Australia.

The Amazon rainforest is the largest and coincides with the Amazon River basin. Its approximate area is 7,000,000 kmÂ².

They have a large quantity and variety of vegetation: large, medium, and small trees, lianas, vines, ferns, shrubs, and herbaceous vegetation, distributed in layers (the tallest trees form a canopy, under which the other species live in a disordered and tangled manner).

They also present a large quantity and variety of animals, for example, monkeys, reptiles, birds, insects, and predatory mammals.

Economic activities are linked to the exploitation of forest and mining resources. Deforestation or the logging of species causes serious consequences, for example, loss of biodiversity, global climate changes, disappearance of animal and plant species, and loss of soils.

Amazon rainforest, Brazil
